title: Man City’s Tommy Doyle working hard to build on family’s legacy with club
text:

Tommy Doyle has vowed to build on his emotional Manchester City debut and continue his family's proud association with the club.

Doyle, 18, who made his debut in Tuesday's 3-1 Carabao Cup win over Southampton , is the grandson of City legends Mike Doyle and Glyn Pardoe.

Mike, who passed away in 2011, captained City to League Cup glory in 1976, while both grandfathers also played in the club's 1969 FA Cup final triumph.

Midfielder Doyle, a lifelong City fan, was handed his debut by Pep Guardiola and, after playing the full 90 minutes, admitted he was still struggling to take it all in.

“It’s very hard to put it into words,” said Doyle. “I’ve been here a long time and you dream of this day - it doesn't seem real.

“To finally do it is a massive thing for me. I’m proud and happy to have made my City debut as I’m not only a player, I’m a fan.

(Image: Getty Images)

“I spoke to my granddad Glyn before and he just said 'Listen, everyone has to do it, so just go out and do what you do'.

“I went out and did the best I can. Hopefully Mike is watching down and is proud of me, because I’ve done it for him as well.

“He did it in a different era and for me to continue the Doyle legacy in a different one is a massive thing.

“Since he died, I’ve always wanted to make him proud, so I’ll keep my head down, listen to all the information I can get and see how far I can go.”

Pardoe, 73, was at the Etihad Stadium to watch his grandson make his City debut – a milestone he achieved three years earlier in 1962, at the age of 15.

“I face-timed him before the game and told him I couldn’t wait,” said Doyle. “He reminded me he was only 15, just getting a little dig in!

(Image: Getty Images)

“He does that all the time, we have a nice healthy competition.

“But he's a legend at this club and I’m fortunate to have him in my family.”

Doyle was just 11 when Sergio Aguero scored his last-gasp winner on the last day of the 2011-12 season to pip local rivals Manchester United to the title.

“I’ve been coming here for years, but the main memory is the Aguero moment, the 93:20,” said Doyle.

“That was the moment that changed everything for the club and put us where we are now.

(Image: Getty Images)

“Now I’m giving passes to Sergio and it doesn’t seem real. He’s a fantastic footballer and gives you lots of information, but keeps it fun, keeps it happy.

“He’s always laughing and joking, which helps calm you down and make you feel better.

“Everyone went mental on that day and to be playing with him is amazing.

“As I walked out of the tunnel, the seat I was in that day is straight ahead.

“It was the first thing I looked at, then I looked at my family in the stands and I was ready.”
description: The 18-year-old Sky Blues starlet is the grandson of Sky Blues legends Mike Doyle and Glyn Pardoe
